ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: I learned how to effectively read, understand, and interpret poetry through different ages. Poetry is an art that I have become more comfortable and inspired by due to this class.
I learned how to analyze text from centuries ago and understand what intentions these writers could've possibly had when creating these texts.
I was exposed to old English poetry, which honestly I wouldn't have read outside the course. I also got practice in writing English papers with consistent feedback to facilitate growth.

I obtained a familiarity with several foundational English poetry works and how to better read and analyze the texts. Part of the course was a general history of English literature, which I found compelling and interesting, even if a background focus. Additionally, I learned how each text interacted with its predecessors and the kind of influence they left for successors.

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: The course is heavy on reading and interpreting poetry on your own. I think this structure works in the favor of both the student and the instructor. Students feel more engaged with the class because they have the time and ability to formulate ideas and thoughts before discussions begin. This assists with how in-class conversations develop and how our essays become more evolved when we dive deeper and deeper into the material.

The essay meetings are very surface level, as we rarely got out of the first paragraph. I think it would be more helpful to have longer sessions in which we moved through the entire essay more quickly. I also think that reasons for grades could be explained more.

I think a significant strength of this course was the writing conferences, as they allowed me to receive very direct feedback for my writing and my approach to writing. I also enjoyed the selection of texts, as the syllabus felt intentional and interrelated. Additionally, only focusing on a smaller quantity of texts gave us more time to explore each work. Something I felt could be improved were the few in-class assignments, as I did not feel like I received a lot of feedback on those and was a little confused on their overall role, especially since it seemed like they decreased as the semester continued.

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: I would HIGHLY recommend this course to anyone interested in studying poetry and generally loves English. Be ready to dive deep into the material and discuss intricate dialogues, descriptions, and lines that will enhance your personal writing skills.
Yes, I feel that the class was taught well and I learned a fair share about writing.
I personally didn't love the reading material and felt really pressured when writing the papers, therefore I wouldn't recommend the course to a non-English major.

I would! I think it was a great course in which I learned a lot and had meaningful discussions. I think this course is a great introduction for anyone interested in English literature, regardless if they had read the texts before, as every time you revisit a text I feel you are certain to find new insights from new perspectives.
